Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometer for Multidiscipline Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Rowan University is acquiring an inductively coupled ionization, mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) to support the research projects in the groups of Professors Lei Yu and colleagues Kauser Jahan, Tabbetha Dobbins, Harold Connolly and James Grinias. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples. An ICP-MS combines a high-temperature and an ionization coupled plasma source with a mass spectrometer. The ICP source converts the atoms of the elements in the sample to ions. These ions are subsequently separated and detected by the mass spectrometer. This is a highly-sensitive analytical technique capable of measuring very low concentrations of metals and non-metals in liquid samples. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students with this modern analytical technique. It is also used in outreach activities involving students and faculty from Chemistry, Geology, and Paleontology. Analysis results are useful for improving the public health and well-being of Camden and other communities in Southern New Jersey.

The award of the mass spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts measurements of the electrochemical oxidation of metal carbides and the dynamic solid-electrolyte-interface change of borohydrides for solid state electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries. The instrumentation is also used for exploring supercritical fluid chromatography combined with ICP-MS for high-throughput synthetic reaction products and catalysts measurements. In addition, it contributes to the analysis of silver-eluting thin films for antimicrobial materials development. The mass spectrometer is also used to understand the solar system by analyzing the aluminum 26- magnesium 26 isotopic ratio. The ICP spectrometer is also employed in studies tracking heavy metal contamination and mitigation in water for environmental protection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

An Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) instrument has been purchased and installed with the support of this MRI grant. Several research projects and research groups use the ICP-MS instrument. These projects include: (1) measuring the metal release mechanisms and kinetics by online electrochemical ICP-MS method, (2) measuring metal contents in animal tissues for the investigation of some diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, and (3) measuring gold nanoparticles in cancer cells, (4) and measuring metal contents in composite catalysts for CO2 electrochemical reduction.

Intellectual Merit

Each of the research projects that use the ICP-MS instrument has its specific intellectual merit. Measuring the metal release mechanism and kinetics can provide fundamental knowledge for the safe design and application of implanted devices. Measuring the contents of metals in different tissues or organs can help to understand the mechanism of many diseases and provide clues for treatments. Measuring the gold nanoparticle contents can provide fundamental knowledge for the use of gold nanoparticles as carriers of drug delivery. Measuring the metal contents in catalysts will be important for the design, characterization, and application of the catalysts for CO2 reduction.

Broader Impacts

In this project, we have involved graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students in the research projects. A Ph.D. student and a M.S. student have been focused on the use of ICP-MS in their research projects. Several undergraduate students form different research groups are using the ICP-MS instrument for different research projects. One high school student used the instrument in her summer research supported by ACS Project SEED program. One high school student used the instrument in her research project. Undergraduate students used the instrument in a teaching lab in the Instrumental Methods course for five semesters. Overall, the ICP-MS instrument has significant impacts on the education and training of students at different levels.

Outcomes

With the support of this grant, we have published/submitted total 3 papers in peer-reviewed journals. Students have presented two posters in internal undergraduate symposium at Rowan University. Results obtained with the instrument have supported the application of one US Patent.

 


Last Modified: 11/17/2023
Modified by: Lei Yu
